query: Do internal Gulfstream documents contradict public communications?
output:
CLAUDE CODE ANALYSIS
Query: Do internal Gulfstream documents contradict public communications?

RELEVANT DOCUMENT EXCERPTS:

[67-107.pdf, p.15]
"heat warning" on #4 brake; therefore, there may be an internal issue within the brake assembly.

[67-107.pdf, p.32]
Do to internal polices and procedures we are unable to work any discrepancies until work is authorized in CMP. While we

[67-107.pdf, p.32]
do appreciate the approvals in the thread below, we are unable to deviate from internal policy.

[Damage Summary Handout for Tribunal.docx, p.1]
Legal Theory: Gulfstream provided a materially misleading proposal—quoting 2,800 labor hours and 35–45 business days—despite having internal forecasting tools, prior inspection data, and knowledge of the Aircraft’s service history.

[Damage Summary Handout for Tribunal.docx, p.1]
Gulfstream had internal data showing G550 inspections at St. Louis routinely exceeded 100–300 days.

[1-110.pdf, p.81]
"heat warning" on #4 brake; therefore, there may be an internal issue within the brake assembly.

[1-110.pdf, p.98]
Do to internal polices and procedures we are unable to work any discrepancies until work is authorized in CMP. While we

[1-110.pdf, p.98]
do appreciate the approvals in the thread below, we are unable to deviate from internal policy.
